segments.en: Linked Discourses 35
8. Sick
75. Sick (2nd)

segments.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu … pe … bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

segments.pli: “amukasmiṃ, bhante, vihāre aññataro bhikkhu navo appaññāto ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: “Sir, in such and such a monastery there’s a mendicant who is junior and not well-known. He’s sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
segments.en: Please go to him out of compassion.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā navavādañca sutvā gilānavādañca, “appaññāto bhikkhū”ti iti viditvā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well-known, he went to him.

segments.pli: Addasā kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
segments.en: That mendicant saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
and tried to rise on his cot.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the Buddha said to that monk,
“It’s all right, mendicant, don’t get up.
There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”

segments.pli: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: He sat on the seat spread out and said to the mendicant,

segments.pli: “kacci te, bhikkhu, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti no abhikkamanti, paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no abhikkamo”ti?
segments.en: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

segments.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ … pe …
segments.en: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. …

segments.pli: na kho maṃ, bhante, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti.
segments.en: I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

segments.pli: “No ce kira te, bhikkhu, attā sīlato upavadati, atha kiñca te kukkuccaṃ ko ca vippaṭisāro”ti?
segments.en: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”

segments.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, bhante, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
segments.en: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”

segments.pli: “No ce kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sīlavisuddhatthaṃ mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsi, atha kimatthaṃ carahi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
segments.en: “If that is so, what exactly do you understand to be the purpose of teaching the Dhamma?”

segments.pli: “Anupādāparinibbānatthaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
segments.en: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.”
“Good, good, mendicant!

segments.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, anupādāparinibbānatthaṃ mayā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāsi.
segments.en: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.

segments.pli: Anupādāparinibbānattho hi, bhikkhu, mayā dhammo desito.
segments.en: For that is indeed the purpose.
“What do you think, mendicant?
Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.” …
“Is the ear …
nose …
tongue …
body …
mind …
mind consciousness …
mind contact …

segments.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
“Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
“Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
“No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati … pe …
segments.en: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye … ear … nose … tongue … body …
mind …
mind consciousness …
mind contact …

segments.pli: Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
segments.en: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.

segments.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
segments.en: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

segments.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandi.
segments.en: Satisfied, that mendicant was happy with what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne tassa bhikkhussa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccīti.
segments.en: And while this discourse was being spoken, the mind of that mendicant was freed from defilements by not grasping.

sections.title: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ……

suttaplex.blurb: Hearing that a newly-ordained mendicant was sick, the Buddha visited him to offer support and Dhamma encouragement.
